address.streetAddress: King St. W and Wellington St W

reviews.title: Old colonial bank
text: Had the pleasure of seeing this lovely building directly from our bedroom on the forty second floor. A very impressive site with a number of gargoyles at the top which you can't see from the ground

reviews.title: Attractive Skyline
text: The Dominion Centre of Toronto is part of the attractive Toronto skyline in the heart of the finanical district. The 2 most impressive buildings are the original 56 story Toronto Dominion Bank Tower and the 46 story Royal Trust Tower with there powerful designs and a granite paved plaza. There is also shopping and restaurants as part of the underground PATH system.

reviews.title: Walking through
text: We were here for a Jane's Walk, for the Animal Sculptures of Toronto.  There are actually two sculptures on the location, between Megaptera and the Pasture.  What is here is interesting, and strange to find in downtown Toronto.  After here we ended up at David Pecaut Sqaure for Remembered Sustenance and then ended at the Shangri La Hotel.

reviews.title: Very Impressed
text: May 10/18 I had a meeting here but what really impressed me was due to inclement weather I was able the use the PATH underground walkway system from the Sheraton Centre 3 blocks away without going out doors. The underground system is fantastic and makes the walking distance which is lined with every imaginable retail and service including restaurants and food courts, feel so much shorter. It probably took me longer to do this walk as I found myself window shopping both directions.

reviews.title: YOU MAY HAVE SEEN THIS BUILDING DESIGN
text: Toronto joined with other cities in developing its downtown skyscrapers and skyline. The TD Complex of straight glass towers in black is a design by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe the design consultant to the architects building the initial 4 towers. Similar looking buildings are seen in Chicago and New York and introduced a new office  building sleek and dark design.

reviews.title: Beautiful building
text: The building itself has a lot of character - inside and out. Great underground as well. The TD staff were also great for all of our banking needs.

reviews.title: Impressive, Iconic Complex
text: The Toronto-Dominion Centre was on my top five attractions to see in the Financial District. The architecture is impressive and it has shops and restaurants in the PATH underneath.

reviews.title: Iconic Toronto Architecture
text: Biased, as I work in the complex, but one of the most Iconic set of buildings in Canada. Starkly contrasting the surrounding buildings exteriors. Amazing underground shopping. Excellent infrastructure. Love TD Centre!

reviews.title: Impressive collection of buildings
text: This impressive collection of buildings made us walk around and we enjoyed the architectonial creativity. Our daughter did jump and rode on several of the metal cows on one of the greens.

reviews.title: Shops and Food
text: Lovely underground building with lots of shops and great eating opportunities. Busy but clean and kept neat and tidy. I would
Recommend going here!

reviews.title: Another Mall
text: Chain stores - that's all. Nothing exciting about it - same stores you would find all the malls in Toronto and suburbs - no special restaurants or bars. If it is cold outside then walk from Union Station north to The Bay or visa versa

reviews.title: Attached to the PATH (underground walkway), good quick food and shopping
text: Easy access from subway, access to food and shopping.  Nice building.

reviews.title: On the Path to Union Station
text: Typical Bank lobby, but very busy as it is the last building before Union Station. Try and stay away at morning and evening rush hours.

reviews.title: Great!
text: You are able to take care of business and do shopping in the Toronto Dominion Centre.  We like this more so than the Eaton Center.  This can be done in the path as well.

reviews.title: Toronto Dominion Centre
text: Toronto Dominion Centre is a maze of shops and dining options in the heart of Toronto's Financial District.  I'm surprised this place doesn't get as much recognition as the Eaton Centre as it's an equally impressive size!

Slightly easy to get lost due to the underground passages, it was thankfully missing a lot of the homeless types that sometimes populate Toronto's other shopping districts.  Everything seemed clean and modern, attracting a lot of business workers from the area.

The TD Bank has a collection of inuit art which can be seen for free.  It was the main reason of my visit but in the short timeframe I was there, I was unable to find it.  Will be back to the TD Centre though and recommend it to others also when in the Financial District.

reviews.title: Toronto Dominion Centre
text: It is a modern skyscap building in downtown Toronto.  It is conncected to a path of more than 6 km of undrground passages with modern shop stores and food courts

reviews.title: Toronto Dominion Centre
text: I actually worked in the Toronto Dominion Centre when it was the tallest building in North America which was a considerable number of years ago and every time I re-visit Canada, I pay a visit to see how much it has changed.  Not that much has changed excepting many taller towers have gone up since.  I was employed on the 47th floor which felt like being in the clouds and it was a pleasure to go to work in such a beautiful place.  The reception area is on the ground floor headed by almost stewardesses directing you to wherever you need to be.  A large bank in the main area  of the building and in the basement a very nice eating place and pub along with post-office, hairdresser, flower shop, chemist and cafes.  There is a beautiful restaurant on the 54th floor which is the top of the building and this feels like you are dining in the clouds.  Working in there I never had to leave the building as in the suites above were dentists, doctors, lawyers, anything you required.  I feel quite honoured to have worked in such a beautiful place.

reviews.title: Back in Black
text: Busy building, but a real standout in black.  Seen it many times in movies and TV as "New York City".  Classic

reviews.title: Half Baked (1998) was filmed here...
text: Interesting buildings and right above the P.A.T.H.  Not worth making a trip to see unless you love to look at office towers.  If you are from a small town and this is your first trip to a big city, grab a coffee at about 7:30am on a weekday and grab a bench.... try to count the people!

reviews.title: Interesting venue
text: Nice to have all those options in Toronto.  Easy enough to get to with the TTC.  It has a lot of appeal for locals and out of towners.

reviews.title: To get a taste of the city's financial pulse
text: To get a taste of the city's financial pulse when it's hungry or in the need of retail therapy stroll through the Toronto-Dominion Centre (and the connecting routes) during lunchtime (but be sure to have eaten first -- the lines are long)... Nontheless, its fun people watching...

reviews.title: Busy, Busy and Busy
text: Very busy place. I went there for some business and was confused as to how to get around. You really need to know this place or you will not find anything. Look it up before you go. You will save lots of time.

reviews.title: Mies van der Rohe!
text: This is Toronto's only building by the famous architect. A three black tower complex surrounding a courtyard. You can get a good impression of his austere modernism and his use of expensive materials. Mies chairs appear sometimes. In the banking hall you will notice yellow daisies in glass vases: they are there as a part of the building by order of the architect. An example of van der Rohe's exacting consideration of every interior detail. Check it out!
Canoe restaurant at the top.

reviews.title: Just down town
text: I would never mark this area as a tourist location- just concrete,2 big buildings like the wtc- only smaller.
